gurmukhi: ਅਾਗੇ ਚਲਾ ਦੱਤ ਜਟ ਧਾਰੀ ॥ ਬਾਜਤ ਬੇਣ ਬਿਖਾਣ ਅਪਾਰੀ ॥ ਅਸਥਾਵਰ ਲਖਿ ਚੇਤਨ ਭੲੇ ॥ ਚੇਤਨ ਦੇਖ ਚਕ੍ਰਿਤ ਹ੍ਵੈ ਗੲੇ ॥੪੩੮॥
transliteration: Aage Chalaa Datt Jat Dhdaree|| Baajat Ben Bikhaan Apdaree|| Asthaavar Lakh(i) Chetan Bhae|| Chetan Dekh Chakrit Hvai Gad||438||
translation: Then Dutt, the wearer of matted locks moved further; the musical instruments were being played; seeing Dutt. The inanimate things were becoming animate and the animate were wonder-struck.438.

gurmukhi: ਮਹਾ ਰੂਪ ਕਛੁ ਕਹਾ ਨ ਜਾੲੀ ॥ ਨਿਰਖ ਚਕ੍ਰਿਤ ਰਹੀ ਸਕਲ ਲੁਕਾੲੀ ॥ ਜਿਤ ਜਿਤ ਜਾਤ ਪਥਹਿ ਰਿਖ ਗਯੋ ॥ ਜਾਨੁਕ ਪ੍ਰੇਮ ਮੇਘ ਬਰਖਯੋ ॥੪੩੯॥
transliteration: Mahaa Roop Kachh(u) Kahaa Na Jaaee|| Nirakh Chakrit Rahisakal Loukaaee|| Jit Jit Jaat Pathah(i) Rikh Gado|| Jaanouk Prem Megh Barkhayo||439||
translation: His great beauty was indescribable, seeing which all the world was in astonishment; the paths on which the sage went, it appeared that the cloud of love was raining.439.

gurmukhi: ਤਹ ੲਿਕ ਲਖ ਸ਼ਾਹ ਧਨਵਾਨਾ ॥ ਮਹਾ ਰੂਪ ਧਰੇ ਦਿਰਬ ਨਿਧਾਨਾ ॥ ਮਹਾ ਜੋਤਿ ਅਰੁ ਤੇਜ ਅਪਾਰੂ ॥ ਅਾਪ ਘੜਾ ਜਾਨੁਕ ਮੁਖਿ ਚਾਹੂ ॥੪੪੦॥
transliteration: Tah Ik Lakh Shaah Dhanvaanaa|| Mahaa Roop Ddare Dirab Nidhaanaa|| Mahaa Jot(i) Ar(u) Tej Apdaroo|| Aap Ghadaa Jaanouk Moukh(i) Chdaroo||440||
translation: There he saw a wealthy trader, was extremely comely and treasure of money and materials; he was supremely splendid and it appeared that Brahma himself had created him.440.

gurmukhi: ਬਿਕ੍ਰਿਅ ਬੀਚ ਅਧਿਕ ਸਵਧਾਨਾ ॥ ਬਿਨ ਬਿਪਾਰ ਜਿਨ ਅੳੁਰ ਨ ਜਾਨਾ ॥ ਅਾਸ ਅਨੁਰਕਤ ਤਾਸ ਬ੍ਰਿਤ ਲਾਗਾ ॥ ਮਾਨਹੁ ਮਹਾ ਜੋਗ ਅਨੁਰਾਗਾ ॥੪੪੧॥
transliteration: Bikria Beech Adhik Savdhaanaa|| Bin Bipaar Jin Aur Na Jaanaa|| Aas Anurakat Taas Brit Laagad|| Maanoh Mahaa Jog Anuraagad||441||
translation: He was extremely conscious about his sale and it seemed that he did not know anything else except trade; absorbed in desires his attention was solely engrossed in trade and he was looking like a great Yogi.441.

gurmukhi: ਤਹਾ ਰਿਖ ਗੲੇ ਸੰਗਿ ਸੰਨਯਾਸਨਿ ॥ ਕੲੀ ਛੋਹਨੀ ਜਾਤ ਨਹੀ ਗਨਿ ॥ ਤਾ ਕੇ ਜਾੲਿ ਦੁਅਾਰ ਪਰ ਬੈਠੇ ॥ ਸਕਲ ਮੁਨੀ ਮੁਨਰਾਜ ੲਿਕੈਠੇ ॥੪੪੨॥
transliteration: Tahaa Rikh Gad San(i) Sannaasan(i)|| Kaichhodhnijaat Nahigad(i)|| Taa Ke Jaae Duaar Par Baithe|| Sakal Mounndmounndaaj Ikaithe||442||
translation: The sage reached there alongwith Sannyasis and innumerable disciples; the great sage Dutt sat at the gate of that trader alongwith many other sages.442.

gurmukhi: ਸ਼ਾਹ ਸੁ ਦਿਰਬ ਬ੍ਰਿਤ ਲਗ ਰਹਾ ॥ ਰਿਖਨ ਓਰ ਤਿਨ ਚਿਤਯੋ ਨ ਕਹਾ ॥ ਨੇਤ੍ਰ ਮੀਚ ੲੇਕੈ ਧਨਿ ਅਾਸਾ ॥ ਅੈਸ ਜਾਨੀਅਤ ਮਹਾ ੳੁਦਾਸਾ ॥੪੪੩॥
transliteration: Shaah Su Dirab Brit Lag Rahaa|| Rikhan Or Tin Chityo Na Kahaa|| Netra Meec Ekai Dhan(i) Aasaa|| Ais Jaaneeaat Mahaa Udaasaa||443||
translation: The mind of the trader was so much absorbed in earning money that he did not pay attention to the sages even slightly; with closed eyes; he was immersed in the expectation of money like a detached hermit.443.

gurmukhi: ਤਹ ਜੇ ਹੁਤੇ ਰਾਵ ਅਰੁ ਰੰਕਾ ॥ ਪੁਨ ਪਗ ਪਰੇ ਛੋਰ ਕੈ ਸ਼ੰਕਾ ॥ ਤਿਹ ਬੈਪਾਰ ਕਰਮ ਕਰ ਭਾਰੀ ॥ ਰਿਖੀਅਨ ਓਰ ਨ ਦ੍ਰਿਸ਼ਟਿ ਪਸਾਰੀ ॥੪੪੪॥
transliteration: Tah Je Houte Raav Ar(u) Rakaa|| Poun Jog Dare Chhodh Kai Shankaa|| Tih Baipaar Karam Kar Bhdaree|| Rikheean Or Na Drishttee Pasdaree||444||
translation: All the kings and poor people who were there, leaving all their doubts fell dwon at the feet of the sages, but that trader was so much immersed in his work that he did not even raise his eyes and see towards the sages.444.

gurmukhi: ਤਾਸ ਦੇਖ ਕਰਿ ਦੱਤ ਪ੍ਰਭਾੳੂ ॥ ਪ੍ਰਗਟ ਕਹਾ ਤਜ ਕੈ ਹਠ ਭਾੳੂ ॥ ਅੈਸ ਪ੍ਰੇਮ ਪ੍ਰਭ ਸੰਗ ਲਗੱੲੀਅੈ ॥ ਤਬ ਹੀ ਪੁਰਖ ਪੁਰਾਤਨ ਪੱੲੀਅੈ ॥੪੪੫॥
transliteration: Taas Dekh Kar(i) Datt Prabhaaoo|| Pragad Kahaa Raj Kai Hath Bhaaoo|| Ais Prem Prabh San Lagadeeeai|| Tab Hipurakh Puraatan Paeeeeai||445||
translation: Dutt looking at his position and impact, leaving his persistence, said openly, “If such a love is employed with the Lord, then that supreme Lord can be realized.”445.
End of the description of the adoption of a Trader as the Twentieth Guru.

gurmukhi: ਅਥ ਸੁਕ ਪੜਾਵਤ ਨਰ ੲਿਕੀਸਵੋਂ ਗੁਰੂ ਕਥਨੰ ॥
transliteration: Ath Souk Padaavat Nar Ikeesavon Guroo Kahanan||
translation: Now begins the description of the adoption of a parrot-instructor as the twenty-first Guru
